reference.title: WH-Entsec-2.4
reference.shortdesc: This file contains conkeyrefs that are exclusive to Enterprise Security 2.4. This is document 41780. The key name is entsec. To use these graphics, this topic must be the first in the Key Definition Map.

li.p: Acknowledge the selected alarm(s) recognizes that an alarm state exists at the point(s) represented by the selected row(s) in the table. This button displays on the Alarm Console view and on the Recurring Alarms view.
Activate Threat Level [Threat Levels > Threat Level Groups]
Add New Person opens the Add New Person view.
Add opens a view or window for creating a new record in the database.
Add Child [Threat Levels > Threat Level Groups]
Add From Default Card Formats Opens a view with the default Wiegand card formats.
Alarm Console [Controller Setup > Alarm Setup > Alarm Consoles]
All Day Event sets up an event that starts at 12 am and ends at 12 am the next day.
Apply M-F configures Monday through Friday using the current day.
Assign moves a discovered item from the Unassigned view to the Assigned view.

Assign All [Controller SetupRemote DevicesRemote ModulesRemote Module Setup, creating a new device or double-clicking the base reader module in the table, clicking the Elevators tab, clicking the Elevator link, clicking the Schedule Floors link, and clicking the chevron to the right of the Floors property.]
Assign Mode off
Assign Mode on
Assign Mode buttons open and close the Unassigned pane.
Assign New Badge opens a view for assigning a badge to the person.
Auto Refresh play [Reports > Intrusion History]
Auto Refresh pause [Reports > Intrusion History]
Auto Refresh Automatically updates the database records displayed in the current table.
Batch Enroll [Personnel > Badges]
Change Assignment Properties opens the Change Assignment Properties window.
Clear Day removes all events on the selected day.
Clear Week removes all events scheduled for the entire selected week.
[Monitoring > click Filter button]
Column Chooser opens the Columns for... view from which you can add data columns to, remove them from, and reorder them in the current table.
Configure opens a properties window.
Console List opens a table view. Each row represents an alarm console.
Copy Day copies all events for the selected day to use with the paste button.
Delete removes the selected record (row) from the database table. This button is available when you select an item.
li.note: Be careful using this button. Once you delete an item from the database view, a discovery action may not find the item.

li.p: Discover opens the Discover window, which defines the database search. Based on this information, the discovery job interrogates the target location for data, such as historical and current point values as well as properties provided by the database.
Download [Controller Setup > Remote Devices > double-click network]
Duplicate opens a New window and populates each property with properties from the selected item. Using this button speeds the item creation.
Edit Alarm Class [Controller Setup > Alarm Setup > Alarm Extensions] [COMMENT: THIS BUTTON NEEDS TO BE CAPTURED AGAIN WHEN THE BUTTON IS ACTIVE.
Edit opens the component’s Edit window.
Edit Entry Point
Edit Always Armed
Edit Instructions [System Setup > Alarm Setup > Alarm Instructions]
Edit Nav [System/Controller Setup > Miscellaneous > Graphics > Graphics Management]
Edit Priority [Controller Setup > Alarm Setup > Alarm Classes]
Edit Time Range [Click a Filter button > click the Edit Time Range button, which is to the right of a time range property.]
Enable/Disable Networks [System/Controller Setup > Remote Devices > Remote Drivers]
Enroll or Enroll New Badge opens the Enroll New Badge view.
Export opens the Export window for creating a PDF or CSV formatted report of the current table.
Filter off [multiple]
Filter on [multiple]

Filter buttons open the Filters window, which defines a query action for limiting the output visible in tables and reports. The gray version indicates unfiltered data. The red version indicates filtered data.
Force Clear
Force Import [System Setup > Remote Devices > Remote Drivers> double-click the Ldap driver > click the LdapServers tab]
Go To Alarm URL [Monitoring] [COMMENT: THIS BUTTON NEEDS TO BE CAPTURED AGAIN WHEN THE BUTTON IS ACTIVE.
Go Into [Threat Levels > Threat Level Groups]
Hyperlink links to the edit view or window for the selected item. It is the same as double-clicking the table row. This button is available when a single record is selected.
Hyperlink to Access Right opens the Edit Access Right view for the access right associated with the selected record.
Hyperlink to Person opens the Edit Person view for the person associated with the selected record.
Hyperlink to Reader opens the reader view, which is documented in the remote devices chapter of the .
Hyperlink Wiegand Formats
Job Log [System/Controller Setup > Miscellaneous > Jobs]
Learn Mode off
Learn Mode on
Learn Mode buttons open and close the Discovered pane in a manager view to show or hide the control buttons and any discovered items (devices, points, database properties, etc.).
Live Video closes the video playback and opens the live camera view.
Manage Reports opens the Manage Reports window from which you can add a report or schedule a report to be emailed.
Manage Devices/Drivers opens the Manage Drivers or Manage Devices window, which is used to Add, Delete, Rename, Duplicate, Copy, and Cut system drivers or devices.
Manual Override [Controller Setup > Intrusion Setup > Intrusion Zones]
Master Instructions [Controller Setup > Alarm Setup > Alarm Instructions]

Match with discovery initiates an action to update a single item that is already in the system database. It is available when you select an item in both the Database pane and the Discovered pane of a manager view. This action associates the discovered item with the selected item that is already in the database—usually an item previously added off line. The added item assumes the properties defined for it in the database. You can edit properties after adding the item.
Match with synchronize combines the properties of similar schedules (subordinate to the Supervisor) and similar personnel records under a single name.
Modify Settings [System/Controller Setup > Miscellaneous > Graphics > Graphics Management]
Move [Threat Levels > Threat Level Groups]
Move Up [for example, Reports > Access History]
Move Down [for example, Reports > Access History]
Move Up and Move Down change the sequence of rows in the direction indicated one selected row at a time.
New [System/Controller Setup > Remote Devices > Station Manager]
Next [for example, Reports > Audit History; appears for all reports when the number of records exceeds the capacity of a single page.]
Notes opens the Alarm Notes window, which provides a text field for adding descriptive information to one or more alarms.
Paste Day places all events copied from another day into the selected day. This button is active only if you used the copy day button first.
or Ping (or wink) sends a command to the remote device or server.
Plays alarm sounds continuously until silenced [Monitoring]
Previous and Next
Previous page and Next page
Print Badge sends the badge data to the printer.
Purge Config opens the Purge Config window for setting up when and how to remove history records from the database.
Quick Edit opens the Quick Edit window for the selected item(s). This feature allows you to edit one or more records without having to leave the current view.
Range Create Badges
Refresh updates the table, clearing row selections in all panes.
Replicate
Remove Nav [System/Controller Setup > Miscellaneous > Graphics > Graphics Management]
Remove Assignment (Unassign) disassociates an assignment that was previously made.
Rename opens the Rename window with which to change the name of the selected item.
Restore [System/Controller Setup > Backups]
Retrieve Active Status [Threat Levels > Threat Level Groups]
Review Video
Save updates the database with the current information.
Set alarm console options [Monitoring]
Selects all visible rows [Monitoring]
Set Com Port [Controller Setup > Remote Devices > double-click network]
Show Access History opens the Access History view for the selected record.
Show Alarm Details opens the Alarm Details window, which provides additional information about the selected alarm.
Show Expirations opens the Person Access Right Report view.
Show open alarms for the selected source [Monitoring]
Show Readers opens the Person Reader Report. The Reports chapter documents this report.
Show Top Level [Threat Levels > Threat Level Groups]
Shows a video off [Monitoring]
Shows a video on [Monitoring]
Shows a video [Monitoring] [The two graphics that make up this pair are: buttonAlarmVideo2.4 and buttonReviewVideo2.4.]
Shows AX AlarmConsole [Monitoring]
Silence all alarm sounds [Monitoring]

Summary opens the Summary window for the selected item, which shows how item properties are currently configured. Double-clicking on any row in a table opens the Summary tab, which contains the same information as the Summary window.
Time Picker [Monitoring]
Toggle sound on or off — on [Monitoring]
Toggle sound on or off — off [Monitoring]
Toggle sound on or off [Monitoring]
Threat Level Groups [Threat Levels > Threat Level Groups > Add]
Turn Off Relays [System Setup > Alarm Setup > add an alarm class > click the Relay
Unassign [Monitoring > Activity monitor]
Up a level [for example, Personnel > add a person > Person tab]
Upgrade Firmware initiates an upgrade of a selected module.
Upload [Controller Setup > Remote Devices > double-click network]
View Graphic [System/Controller Setup > Miscellaneous > Graphics> Graphic Management]

Wink Device cycles the first digital output (relay output) for all selected devices on and off for a period of 10 seconds. This confirms that the device is responding before matching it to a specific component in the station database (typically, after you have added offline hardware are using the match function.
Preferences [System/Controller Setup > Remote Devices >Access Video Network > Cameras tab]; also called Settings/Configure.
Acknowledge recognizes that the alarm state exists.
Add New Person opens the Add New Person view.
Assign New Badge opens the Badge tab.
Change Layout opens the Select Layout window, which configures the Alarm Console view.
Console List opens a table view. Each row represents an alarm console.
Duplicate opens the Add New Person window with duplicate properties.
Enroll New Badge opens the Enroll New Badge view.
Filter opens the Filters window used to define a query for the purpose of limiting system output to only selected criteria.
Notes opens the Notes window, which is used to add a note to one or more selected alarms.
Review Video opens the Alarm Video viewer for reviewing video that is recorded as a result of an alarm. This link is only available when an alarm video is available.
Save updates the station database with the current information.
Show Recurring opens the Recurring Alarms view for a single, selected point, and changes to the Show All returns to the Alarm Console view, which reports alarms on all points.
Silence stops any audible notification associated with an alarm.
Alarm Console [Home]
Ascending [table views]
Descending [table views]
Station Save [Home]
Tenant Filter [Home]
Tenant Lock [On a table with Tenants, click chevron >select tenant and assign > click Tenant Filter icon > click chevron and assign a tenant]
Pop Out In New Window [Home]
[Home].
[Home]

section.title: Paragraphs
section.p: If there is only one console recipient, the system automatically assigns it to the class or zone when creating a new alarm class or intrusion zone. If additional console recipients are available, you must manually choose and assign the console recipient using the Recipients tab before saving the new alarm class or intrusion zone.

Both a DVR and an NVR record video. They differ in where they process the video stream and in the type of camera each requires:
DVRs are wired security systems that use analog cameras. They process and store video data at the recorder.
NVRs can be wired or wireless systems. Most require IP cameras. NVRs encode and process video at the camera, then stream the video to the recorder, which provides storage and remote viewing.

section.title: Columns
section.p: The divs under Description report information on reports and can also be used on views. In other words, there is no need to create a separate div in a Properties table for a read-only property that is reporting information. For example, the description for Open Alarm Count in a properties table can come from the two-column table.

entry.div: Identifies the title of the access right associated with the entity.

Defines the name of the account expiry attribute in the LDAP server. Some LDAP servers configure user accounts to expire on a specific date and time. This name identifies the attribute that contains this information.
The security system’s import job ignores data from any user account that has expired.
Indicates if the alarm must be acknowledged (true) or not (false).
Reports the state of the alarm (unacknowledged, acknowledged).
Displays the time that the alarm was acknowledged (if applicable).
Displays a list of values, which indicate a valid user status. This list is specific to your organization’s personnel policies.
Defines if users may be added before they are activated in the system.
Reports the Display Name of the alarm class associated with the point, recipient or other component.

Shows the initial source state that caused the alarm to be generated. The Alarm Transition may not be the current state of the alarm source. Once an Alarm Transition is created, it does not change for a single alarm record. For example, if the source state returned to “Normal” after an “Offnormal” status, this value remains at “Offnormal”.
Configures if users may be added to the LDAP server before they are activated in the system.
Reports the threat level assignment.
If the alarm was triggered by an access control violation, identifies the responsible badge.
Reports the sequential number assigned to the badge. The card reader uses this number to validate access.
Reports where within the organization’s flow chart the person works.
Provides a meaningful word or short phrase to help you remember the purpose or characteristics of the badge.
Reports if the function is turned on (true) or off (false).
Reports the final date from the schedule.
Reports the current state of fallback enforcement (Off, Soft, or Hard), which is assigned to the zone.
entry.draft-comment: [COMMENT: WHAT IS FALLBACK ENFORCEMENT? WHERE IS IT CONFIGURED?]

entry.div: Identifies the physical building, organization or campus where the badge may be used.
Reports the given name of the person.
Reports the name of the associated integration ID. The system performs building automation actions, such as turning the lights on, associated with this type of ID.
Displays the total number of alarm sources.
Reports the family name of the person.
Displays the time the system most recently updated the alarm.
Describes how to handle an alarm.
Displays the customized message created for this alarm.
Reports the next date and time this event will occur. This could be a beginning or ending of a scheduled event. If the next event is more than a year into the future, this column reports null.

row.entry: Next Value (same as for propdesc Next Value)

entry.div: Reports the next scheduled out value (true or false) to occur at Next Time. This value is meaningless if Next Time is null.
When displayed, shows a null value until the point returns to a normal state, then it displays the time that the point status returned to normal.
Displays the total number of current alarms. An alarm is considered to be open when it is not acknowledged and normal or not acknowledged and in alarm.
Reports the current out value.
Reports the name of the employee.
Reports additional information about the person.
Reports the type of data compression the camera is currently configured to use.
Reports the camera’s currently-configured resolution.
Indicates the source of Fox video streaming.

Reports the priority level assigned to the alarm class for each component state transition (from normal to Offnormal, from normal to Fault, from offnormal, fault or alert to Normal, and from normal to Alert).The lower the number, the more significant the alarm. The highest priority alarm (most significant) is number 1.The lower the number, the more significant the alarm. The highest priority alarm (most significant) is number 1.
Reports the name of the reader associated with the access right.
Reports the name of the associated schedule (if any).
Reports if you are using fox or foxs for communication. Foxs uses TLS encryption and server authentication and is more secure than fox communication.
Reports the component that transitioned from normal to offnormal, fault, or alert. If defining search criteria, you can use wild cards here.

Reports the component state transition:
Offnormal (normal to offnormal)
Alert (normal to alert)
Fault (normal to fault)
Normal (offnormal, alert, or fault to normal)
Reports the beginning date from the schedule.
Reports the name of the station under the control of which the event occurred.

div.div: Reports the current condition of the entity as of the last refresh: {alarm}, {disabled}, {down}, {fault}, {ok}, {stale}, {unackedAlarm}.

entry.div: Reports the current state of the badge: Issuable (currently unassigned), Active, Disabled, Lost or Unknown.
Reports the name of the station under whose control the event occurred.
Reports the name of the associated tenant.
Reports the name of the associated threat level group.
Reports the length of time the system waits after someone sets the alarm before it arms the zone.
Reports the time that the system generated the last alarm assigned to this alarm class.
Reports when the transition from normal occurred, triggering the alarm.
Reports when the record was written to the database.
Defines the station path for this zone.
Displays the total number of alarms assigned to the alarm class from all sources.
Displays the total number of unacknowledged alarms.
Helps to identify the schedule and provide filtering options when choosing a schedule from a list.

If the alarm was triggered by an access control violation, identifies the person associated with the badge. If the alarm was generated by malfunctioning equipment, identifies the system user, if known.
Unique Universal Identifier
Reports the length of time the system sounds a warning before arming a zone.
Identifies the wiring standard for the card reader.
Reports the last value written using device facets. Applies only to writable points.

property.propvalue: minutes and seconds (1 second to 59 minutes)

propdesc.div: Defines the length of time that a door may remain unlocked after access is granted. Values are only used when Auto Relock is set to Unlock Time.

property.propvalue: drop-down list (defaults to Load Newest Alarm)

propdesc.div:
For video alarms, determines alarm console behavior when a new alarm (with video) occurs.
Load Newest Alarm automatically displays video associated with the latest alarm.
Manual Alarm Selection displays no video until you select an alarm in the console.

property.propvalue: drop-down list (defaults to Load Newest Alarm)

propdesc.div:
Determines the video alarm console behavior when a video alarm is acknowledged from the video alarm controls.
Load Newest Alarm automatically displays the video associated with the acknowledged alarm.
Manual Alarm Selection displays no video until you select the alarm in the console.

Defines alarm routing options and priorities. Typical alarm classes include High, Medium and Low. An alarm class of Low might send an email message, while an alarm class of High might trigger a text message to the department manager.
Enables (on) and disables (off) the alarm console popup feature. When enabled, new alarms open an alarm popup window. Set AlarmConsolePopup=AllAlarms for the admin user.
Defines the path to a graphic file to add to the display in the Timestamp column of the alarm table in the Console Recipient view.
Creates instructions that appear in the Alarm Record window regarding how to handle the alarm. This is a way to provide information that may be important of helpful to the person monitoring alarms.
Links to a set of properties for configuring and routing alarms. These properties are documented in the Alarm Setup topic of the PDF and in the help system (search for Alarm Source Info).

Prevents nuisance alarms caused by momentary changes in a state value (Normal, Low Limit, High Limit) by defining the minimum time period that an alarm condition must continuously exist before the object alarms. At the expiration of this time, an alarm is generated if the offnormal condition still exists.
Alarm Time Delay does not affect alarms generated by a fault. There is no delay when transitioning in or out of a fault-generated alarm.
Alarm Time Delay applies to entities that transition both in and out of alarm states. Therefore, an alarm status may continue to display as Offnormal (for example) for a time (equal to the time delay) after the value has come back to normal. The time delayis a minimum time period that a normal condition must exist before the object comes out of alarm.
Sets up a query to customize the history report.
Turns on (true) and off (false) the use of an auto log-off time. If set to true , an Auto Logoff Time is required.
Defines the maximum time a user may remain inactive before the system logs the user off. This security measure takes effect when Auto Logoff Enabled set to true.

Defines what should happen with a door that has just been unlocked.
Unlock Time permits the door to remain unlocked for the amount of time defined by Access Unlock Time.
Relock On Door Open locks the door as soon at it unlocks.
Relock On Door Close locks the door either after the Access Unlock Time expires (if the door has been unlocked, but not opened) or when the door closes.

property.propvalue: read-only with link to the Wire Sheet

propdesc.div: Identifies the base AlarmService.

Deletes events.
true configures the system to delete one-time special events that will not occur again. When a special event is deleted, a message is sent to the schedule log, and that special event no longer appears on the Special Events tab.
Applies to table columns. The topic “entse-ConsolidatedColumnsProvider” topic documents this property.
Enables (true) and disables (false) intrusion record consolidation in the Supervisor station. The Supervisor station can consolidate data from all remote stations configured for an intrusion keypad.

Configures intervals between actions and timeout values. These settings affect how long a camera continues to respond to control communications after a control message is received. The reason for these limits is to prevent a camera from being left in a state of continual movement or adjustment (iris, focus, or zoom) in case communication with the device is lost.
Assigns a sequential number to a badge. The card reader uses this number to validate access.
Configures when the data expire.

Defines a specific threat level to associate with an access right.
If you leave this property set to –Default–, the access right inherits the threat level from the Default Access Right Threat Level property as defined for the selected threat level group.
Configures a filter for local history.
Defines the person’s department number.
Defines a meaningful word or short phrase to help you remember the purpose or characteristics of the badge.
Provides additional information, which could include the camera’s geographical location or other unique information.
Configures a string that matches the device names from station(s) that are exporting histories The default matches all station names.
Sets up the Base Extent properties. The “query-SingleExtent” topic documents these properties.

property.proptype: Elevated Threat Level (appears when you assign a Threat Level Group to the reader.)

propdesc.div: Defines a threat level for changing the reader configuration. The default ignores any active threat level changes.

property.proptype: Elevated Threat Reader Config (appears when you assign a Threat Level Group to the reader.)

propdesc.div: Specifies a reader configuration to enable when the active threat level matches or exceeds the Elevated Threat Level.

Displays and hides the video setting properties. When set to false, the following properties do not display in the view: Layout, Alarm Console Popup, Action on New Alarm, and Action On Video Acknowledgment.

Displays a unique identifier for a particular EntsecAsureID (non-legacy) device and is provided automatically during discovery. After manually adding the EntsecAsureID device, you match with the discovered device to populate this property.
Identifies the port used for the EntsecAsureId connector.

Configures the date and time after which each badge is no longer authorized for use:
never indicates that the badge does not expire.
Six date options: Month, Day, Year, hour, minutes, and AM/PM.

Sets a predetermined expiration date for a user.
never configures the user to never expire.
Date option properties—Activates the six date option properties. Edit the Month, Day and Year to set a user expiration date. Edit the hour, minutes, and AM/PM properties set an expiration time.

property.propdesc: Determines how values are formatted for display depending on the context. For example, instead of true and false you may want to display Access Granted and Access Denied or Locked and Unlocked as your options. Sometimes you define facets by entering text properties. Other times access to facets is by clicking. >>, which opens an Edit Facets window.

propdesc.div: Identifies the physical building, organization or campus where the badge may be used.
Fine tunes the end time.
Defines the person’s given name.
Defines from which node in the LDAP server to begin searching for groups (access rights).
For group records, defines the objectClass (metadata) associated with each record that identifies it as a group record versus a system or other record type in the server database.

Defines how much of the LDAP server to search.
Object Scope
One Level Scope
Subtree Scope extends the scope to the child nodes of the node defined in the Group Search Base expression.

Configures a string that matches the names of histories being exported. The default matches all history names.Both Device Pattern and History Name Pattern must apply for the rule to be used—otherwise the software evaluates the next rule down (in order) for History Policies.
Reports the type of record.
Defines the IP address and path to the video server. It is required for HTML5 streaming and to record motion-detected video.
Defines where the icon used for this column is located.
Includes (true) and excludes (false) histories from the local station.
Includes (true) and excludes (false) histories exported from remote stations.

Indicates what happens to a door-forced-open alarm during an exit request.
true indicates that the door-forced-open alarm stays inhibited during an exit request. This is only possible if Status is Active and Enabled Schedule is true. If either changes, Inhibit Sensor changes from true to false after a time that is equal to the Access Unlock Time.
false indicates the door-forced-open alarm manifests during an exit request.

Defines the number of doors.
No Doors
One Door
Two Doors
Defines the maximum amount of time permitted to elapse between frames. A video stream that takes longer than this amount of time to retrieve a video frame needs to be re-established.

Defines when each badge is authorized for use. Two options are possible:
TBA (to be assigned) allows the issue date to be defined at a later time.
Six data options: Month, Day, Year, hour, minutes and AM/PM define the issue date.

property.propvalue: list of two-character language codes, defaults to the language used by the browser

propdesc.div: Specifies a lexicon (for example: fr or de), which configures language support or other customized values, if available, in the system.
Reports the last time the job failed.
Reports the cause for the most recent job failure.
Indicates the last time that the schedule was modified.
Defines the person’s family name.
Reports the last time the job succeeded.
Lists the display options that are available for the Alarm Console - Live view. The options determine what information the live console view displays. Some layouts include one or more video feeds.

Manages the log for a scheduled activity.
true creates a record any time a schedule controls activity at this door. The record may be displayed in the Access History report.
false disables the recording of scheduled activity.
Opens a window for managing facet keys and values.

property.propvalue: hours minutes seconds (defaults to five seconds)

propdesc.div: Configures a minimum time for the Supervisor station to consolidate input from the remote controller stations.

Defines an identifier for the nav group. This name appears in the menu if no Display Name is specified. You may want to use this property for a design-logical name and use the Display Name as a more user-friendly name.

Defines if this user definition can be used in other stations.
false defines a user that is local to this particular station only.
true automatically replicates (or propagates) the user to subordinate stations that are joined under a Supervisor station.

Describes the physical space where a tenant card holder typically resides in a facility. This information may be passed to a building automation system by BACnet, for example, so that when a person exercises this access right by entering the facility, the appropriate lighting, HVAC, and other controls adjust automatically.

Defines if a note is required. true requires a user to enter a note when acknowledging an alarm.
true requires a user to enter a note when acknowledging an alarm
false disables this requirement.
Defines a value that the system routes to the access device at the scheduled times.
Automatically fills (if you enrolled the person from another view), or defines the owner using the Ref Chooser. The person to whom the badge is assigned is the badge owner.

Defines where in the hierarchy to place a new menu item. A hierarchy of options matches the current navigation structure. You can choose the menu or submenu here to specify where, in the overall system navigation hierarchy, to place your new menu item.
For example, to place a menu item under the Remote Devices submenu, choose the Remote Devices option in this property.

Defines an attribute that describes the person. Possibilities include: Supervisor, Manager, Operator, Local, Remote, Home Office, Satellite Office, Exempt, Hourly. If this property is empty, the system uses the default Person Type. If the property does not match an existing Person Type, the system creates a new type.
Sets up a query to retrieve database records. A separate topic documents these properties.

property.propvalue: two properties with Add, Edit and Delete buttons

propdesc.div: Defines a set of pre-defined camera instructions each as a pair that consists of an integer (ordinal) and text command for controlling the camera. What to enter here depends on the camera.
Sets up the required hardware to validate an entry request, as well as a request to arm or disarm an intrusion zone.
Reports the last value read using device facets.

Defines how the relay out behaves relative to the assigned input. You can toggle relay settings on and off or the relay may be out of phase (inverse) with the assigned input.
Follow matches the state of the assigned input.
Inverse selects the relay out status that is the opposite of the assigned input state.
Toggle on active changes the relay from its current state when the assigned input state changes to active.
Toggle on inactive changes the relay from its current state when the assigned input state changes to inactive.

Selects how much data to report.
Optimized limits the amount of data on the report.
Full Report outputs all data.
Displays the type of table row.
Defines the user name required by RTSP to control the camera.
Defines the password required by RTSP to control the camera.
Defines how far into the future the system looks when calculating the Next Time or Next Value property. Make sure that this value is always positive and always greater than 24 hours.

property.proptype: Schedule Lockdown Threat Level (Appears when you assign a Threat Level Group to the strike.)

propdesc.div: Specifies a threat level that keeps the door locked no matter what the state of the associated schedule is. The default sets the door to follow the associated schedule without regard to the active threat level. A value other than the default (Low, Normal or High) keeps the door locked as long as the active threat level is at or above that specified here. This value must be greater threat than the value specified in the Unlock Threat Level. If not, the system displays a warning message next to the property when you try to save.

Specifies when to set the strike status. All options work with the selected unlock schedule. If no schedule is selected, (property set to none), none of the options are available for specifying how to set the strike status.
Normal follows the schedule defined by the Unlock Schedule property.
Unlock on first validation causes the strike to unlock (if access is granted) and remain unlocked after the first time access is granted within the scheduled open time. If access is granted outside of the scheduled open time, an unlock-on-first-validation is not performed.
Unlock and Relock alternately unlocks and re-locks with each card swipe.
Follow Another Strike opens a Ref Chooser used to select a module and door strike to follow. Door status reflects the status of the strike to follow. Choosing this option, when the schedule is true, inhibits the door force alarm without waiting for the door to follow to have its strike enabled.
Defines how much of the User Search Base to actually search.

Reports the name of the alarm source. If you use the default script setting (%parent.displayName%), the source name property shows the display name of the alarm extension parent. You can edit this script, or type in a literal string.

div.p: Normal (offnormal, alert, or fault to normal)

propdesc.div: Fine tunes the start time. For any event, this time is inclusive. The event extends to, but does not include the end time. In other words, there is no output “blip” between adjacent events, even across days. For example, if a Monday event ends at midnight, a Tuesday event starts at midnight. Schedule output continues, provided both events have the same Output value.
Reports “Issueable” until the badge is assigned, then it may be Active, Disabled, Lost or Unknown.
Indicates the current state of the sensor (Active or Inactive), and its status {ok}, or other possibilities.
Defines the company name of the associated tenant.
Assigns a tenant to the threat level. This helpful meta data provides a way to filter output.

property.proptype: Threat Level Operation (appears only when a Threat Level Group is assigned)

propdesc.div:
Defines how the access right responds to a threat level.
Normal allows normal access (as if no threat level is assigned) when the currently-active threat level is equal to or less than the threat level assigned to the person’s access right.
Specific Level allows normal access (as if no threat level is assigned) as long as the currently-active threat level is equal to the threat level assigned to the person’s access right.
Reverse allows normal access (as if no threat level is assigned) as long as the currently-active threat level is equal to or greater than the threat level assigned to the person’s access right.
Reverse allows some types of people (emergency responders) into a facility when the active threat level is elevated.
Reports the Nrio Universal Input point type: Resistive Input, Boolean Output, etc.
Allows an exit request to unlock a door.
Selects a schedule to indicate when a door should be unlocked. None disables all strike properties. If no schedules appear in the Ref Chooser, none may have been created yet.

Specifies a threat level that keeps the door unlocked, no matter what the state of the associated schedule is.
The default follows the associated schedule without regard to the active threat level. A value other than the default (that is, Low, Normal or High) keeps the door unlocked as long as the active threat level is at or below the level specified here. The value of the Schedule Lockdown Threat Level must be a greater threat level than the value specified by this property, otherwise, a warning message displays when you try to save changes.
Indicates how frequently new information is reported.

Defines where to start searching for personnel in the LDAP server hierarchy.
ou stands for organizational unit.
dc stands for domain controller.
dn stands for distinguished name. This name both uniquely identifies an entry in the LDAP database and describes its position in the hierarchy.
For personnel, defines the objectClass (metadata) associated with each record that identifies it as a personnel record versus a system or other record type in the server database.
Enables (true) and disables (false) Ssl (Secure Sockets Layer) for communication with a host email server that requires it.
Enables (true) and disables (false) Tls (Transport Layer Security) for a host email server that requires it.

Turns RTSP (Real Time Streaming Protocol) on and off. This protocol controls a camera using DVD-style controls (play, pause, etc.)RTSP does not support TLS secure communication. Using this protocol may open your video network to be hacked.
true enables RSTP streaming.
false enables standard video streams at the camera, typically: H264 or MPEG4.
Indicates if the Real Time Streaming Protocol is in use.
Turns on and off use of the channel that handles TCP (Transport Control Protocol) communication between the station and the camera.
Opens the Video Setup window, which selects, enables and configures a video camera to associate with the alarm point or device.

Defines the port, when using the web UI, over which to transmit the camera’s video signal. 443 supports only secure communication between the camera and the station.
For a camera that does not support TLS secure communication, that is, if Use Rtsp Stream is true or if you are using the HTTP protocol (Use Tls is false and Use Rtsp Stream is false), change this property to 80.Be aware that the framework cannot prevent a flooding attack or other malicious activity if you choose to configure your application without secure communication.
If using fox streaming, which uses the station to render the video stream, this port should be different from the station’s fox port. If you are not using fox streaming, this port should be the same as the station’s fox port.
Defines the action to perform on the binding of the target component when an event is fired by the parent widget.
Opens the Ref Chooser window used to assign a Wiegand Format from the list of available formats.

When its status transitions from disabled to enabled, defines a writeable proxy point’s behavior.
true initiates a write when the transition occurs.
false prevents a write when the transition occurs.

At station startup, defines a writeable proxy point’s behavior.
true initiates a write when the station first reaches a steady state.
false prevents a write when the station first reaches a steady state.

When the point and its parent device transition from down to up, defines a writeable proxy point’s behavior.
true initiates a write when the transition occurs.
false prevents a write when the transition occurs.
Reports the last value written using device facets. Applies only to writable points.
